title: 105_hr3342
content:
The Act titled "Patient Safety and Health Care Whistleblower Protection Act of 1998" prohibits discrimination or retaliation. The Act prohibits retaliation or discrimination against health care workers who disclose information, advocate for patients, or participate in investigations related to a health care entity. It also prohibits retaliation for attempted actions described in the Act. The Act prohibits retaliation or discrimination against health care workers for disclosing information, advocating for patients, or participating in investigations related to a health care entity. It also protects health care workers from being restricted in taking actions protected under the Act. The section does not protect disclosures that violate laws or diminish confidentiality rights. Good faith actions are defined for health care workers disclosing information under subsection (a)(1). The Act prohibits retaliation or discrimination against health care workers for disclosing information that violates laws or standards, potentially endangering patients or the public. SEC. 3. CONFIDENTIALITY OF COMPLAINTS TO GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. The identity of a health care worker who complains in good faith about the quality of care to a government agency shall remain confidential unless there is imminent danger to health or public safety. Private Cause of Action allows health care workers to file civil actions in Federal or State courts against those who violate section 2, with potential damages including compensatory, punitive damages, reinstatement, and reimbursement of lost compensation. Interest on damages awarded is also included. The court can issue injunctive relief to restrain violations of the law, including withholding of payment and changes in employment terms. An action must be brought within 2 years of the violation. Violators may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000. Any person who violates section 2 may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation. The penalty amount will be determined based on the size of the business and the severity of the violation. The penalty can be deducted from any sums owed by the United States to the violator or ordered by the court in a lawsuit brought by the affected health care worker. Willful and repeated violations related to a pattern of violations or quality of care may result in criminal penalties. Any person who violates section 2 may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation, determined by business size and violation severity. Willful and repeated violations may result in criminal penalties, including fines, imprisonment, or both for actions leading to serious harm or retaliation against healthcare workers. SEC. 5. BURDEN OF PROOF. In any civil action under this Act, the complainant must show that discriminatory behavior was a contributing factor in the alleged adverse action. Once a prima facie case is established, the burden shifts to the respondent to prove otherwise. In a civil action, the burden shifts to the respondent to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the same adverse action would have been taken even without the discriminatory behavior. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "health care entity" as including facilities and carriers, as well as agencies overseeing health care. "Health care worker" includes employees directly employed or contracted by a health care entity, such as nurses, physicians, and support staff. The term "discrimination or retaliation" in the Act includes adverse actions against health care workers, such as threats or changes in employment terms. "Care, services, or conditions" encompass all aspects of patient care provided by health care entities. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "person" and "Secretary" in relation to health care entities and the provision of health care services. It includes details about the entities covered under the term "person" and specifies that the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 7. NOTICE.

Each health care entity must post a notice approved by the Secretary on its premises, summarizing key provisions of the Act and information on filing charges. Employers face a penalty of up to $100 for willful violations.

SEC. 8. NONPREEMPTION.

The Act does not override other laws and does not limit states' authority to enact laws providing equal or greater protections for health care workers. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act applies to retaliation or discrimination acts occurring after the enactment date.
